results.title: Sleep for health
results.brief_description: Presents the importance of regular sleeping habits from the viewpoint of a child. Shows the child how a regular bed-time which allows for sufficient sleep helps them attain goals which they desire. Emphasises the child’s own responsibility in the formation of good habits. Considers dreaming as a normal part of sleeping. Illustrates how lack of sleep causes irritability and interferes with the enjoyment of everyday living.

results.title: Sleep and dreaming
results.creator_credit: Carol Trussell and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
What is sleep? What are dreams and what use, if any, do they have? The average person spends seven and a half hours asleep and a third of that time dreaming. Freud was the first person to attempt a coherent theory of dreams, although his idea of the dream being a special access to the repressed unconscious which holds the secret of mental disorders, has largely been discredited. Now sleep patterns can be accurately measured but there are still no proven explanations for dreams. This program explores some of the latest research into these two mystifying areas.

results.title: Sleep
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
We spend a third of our lives asleep. This program looks at the structure of sleep and disturbances to that structure, such as nightmares and sleepwalking, sleep disorders such as narcolepsy and what happens when our normal daily patterns of sleep and wakefulness, day and night are interrupted.

results.title: Sleep
results.brief_description: Talks about what sleep is; why we need it; what happens to the body during sleep. It makes parallels between human and animal sleep. Suitable for middle primary level.

results.title: Slavery and slave resistance
results.creator_credit: Dynamic Films, Perspective Films and Maurice Barf
results.brief_description: Conducted by a young African American youth speaking from a graphic display of artifacts, historical documents, newspapers and pictures, the film traces the origins of slavery and examines the basis of racial stereotyping as it developed in the dehumanising conditions of slave life and work.

results.title: Slave hunter = Rancheador
results.creator_credit: Instituto Cubano del Arte e Industrias Cinematográficos (ICAIC) and Sergio Giral
results.brief_description: Against the historic backdrop of the colonial slave era in the Caribbean and other parts of Latin America, the figure of the Rancheador (slave hunter) appeared as one of the most abominable exponents of the system. The Rancheador, the mercenary of his era, was in charge of hunting down runaway slaves, the cimarrones, and returning them to their owners, or if the hunt ended in death, bringing back the slave’s ear. Francisco Estevez, one of the bloodiest and most ambitious slave hunters in Cuban history, was hired by the rich landowners to police the interests of absentee sugar growers. This film is based on the diary of Estevez himself, who not only hunted down the runaway slaves in their palenques (communities concealed in the hills, made up of runaway slaves), but also used his henchmen to repress all outbursts of rebellion or desire for freedom of those either white or black, free or slave. ‘Rancheador’ is the second film of Giral’s Slave Trilogy that also includes ‘The Other Francisco’ (1974) and ‘Maluala’ (1979). Adapted from ‘Diary of a Rancheador’ by Villaverde. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Slaughterhouse five
results.creator_credit: Paul Monash, Universal Pictures and George Roy Hill
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Kurt Vonnegut, an American P.O.W. is slipping into mental illness. Now a suburban optometrist, he has space/time fantasies, shifting between his experiences as a POW, including the bombing of Dresden, his life on another planet and his actual life. Michael Sacks plays Billy Pilgrim in a film shot in Czechoslovakia and Minnesota, which captures the complexity of Vonnegut’s work, and the despair of mental illness
